Introduction

Paralytic ileus is a functional defect in bowel motility, which slows or stops the transit of intestinal contents without a physical obstruction.  It typically occurs after abdominal surgery but may also be associated with medications, trauma, and serious medical conditions (eg, sepsis).  Diminished peristalsis leads to the accumulation of gas and fluid in the bowel, causing abdominal distension, discomfort, nausea, and hypoactive/absent bowel sounds.  Abdominal imaging typically reveals uniformly dilated, gas-filled loops of small and large bowel.  Management is conservative and includes bowel rest.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Paralytic ileus involves the reduction or complete cessation of intestinal peristalsis, which limits the forward propulsion of intestinal contents and leads to bowel dilation.  It is a functional obstruction that occurs in the absence of any anatomic or mechanical blockage (eg, mass, adhesions).  The condition may be triggered by:



  • Surgery, especially abdominal or pelvic surgery (most common cause)
  • Trauma, particularly involving the abdomen
  • Intraabdominal inflammation (eg, peritonitis, pancreatitis, abscess, appendicitis)
  • Use of opioid analgesics or other medications that reduce intestinal motility (eg, anticholinergics)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia)
  • Postoperative or intraoperative retroperitoneal/abdominal hemorrhage
  • Intestinal ischemia
  • Severe systemic infections (eg, sepsis)


Paralytic ileus results from dysfunction of the neuroimmune systems that regulate gastrointestinal motility.  The mechanism by which paralytic ileus occurs is complex and likely involves a combination of:



  • Inflammation:  Intestinal irritation or manipulation (eg, during surgery) initiates an inflammatory cascade, which involves the release of antiperistaltic agents (eg, cytokines) and inhibitory neurotransmitters that alter smooth muscle function and decrease motility.
  • Neural reflexes:  Noxious stimuli increase inhibitory sympathetic output from the autonomic nervous system to the gut, decreasing intestinal smooth muscle activity.
  • Pharmacologic effects:  Medications that decrease peristalsis and slow intestinal motility (eg, opioids) can lead to or exacerbate paralytic ileus.

Pathology



Paralytic ileus affects all segments of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to dilation of the small and large intestines due to gas and fluid accumulation.  The bowel walls may appear edematous and inflamed, with reduced or absent peristaltic activity.  Unlike mechanical obstruction, in paralytic ileus, there is no physical blockage or transition point (ie, bowel dilation proximal to mechanical obstruction with collapsed bowel distally).

Clinical presentation



Patients with paralytic ileus typically present with:



  • Diffuse, mild abdominal pain, often described as discomfort (rarely severe)
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Inability to tolerate oral intake
  • Absence of flatus and bowel movements


Characteristic examination findings include:



  • Hypoactive or absent bowel sounds
  • Mildly tender or nontender on abdominal palpation
  • Abdominal distension
  • Possible dehydration and electrolyte imbalances due to poor oral intake (in severe cases)

Differential diagnosis



  • Small bowel obstruction (
    image 1
    ):  is a mechanical blockage often caused by a hernia, a tumor, or postsurgical adhesions.  Symptoms include abdominal distension and nausea/vomiting, but abdominal pain is severe, and bowel sounds are typically hyperactive (not hypoactive).  Distinguishing features on x-ray include air-fluid levels and a clear transition point.
  • Perforated abdominal viscus (
    image 2
    ):  is a tear in the bowel wall that commonly causes free air under the diaphragm, as well as diffuse abdominal tenderness with rebound and guarding (due to peritonitis).
  • Colonic pseudoobstruction (Ogilvie syndrome) (
    image 3
    ):  is an acute dilation of the colon (usually the cecum or right side of the colon) with no anatomic obstruction.  Like paralytic ileus, it is caused by dysregulation of motility after surgery or severe illness.  However, the small bowel is unaffected, and elderly patients in long-term care facilities are most often affected.
  • Toxic megacolon (
    image 4
    ):  is a potential complication in ulcerative colitis and severe Clostridioides difficile colitis; it presents with colonic dilation, obstipation (inability to have bowel movements), vomiting, and hemodynamic instability.  The small bowel is not affected, and severe colonic dilation (>6 cm) with loss of haustral folds is characteristic.
  • Severe constipation (
    image 5
    ):  can present with distension and abdominal discomfort, but patients typically have normal bowel sounds and a less severe clinical picture (eg, vomiting and intolerance of oral intake is uncommon).  X-ray reveals excessive stool in the colon.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is clinical based primarily on history and physical examination findings; imaging is typically used to confirm the diagnosis and rule out mechanical obstruction, which can present with similar symptoms (

Paralytic ileus should be suspected in patients with nausea/vomiting; a soft, distended abdomen; and hypoactive bowel sounds, especially within days of surgery.  Whereas mechanical small bowel obstruction typically occurs weeks to years after surgery, ileus most often develops within days of bowel manipulation.



Imaging (eg, abdominal x-ray, CT scan) that reveals gaseous distension of both the small and large bowels, gas in the colon/rectum, the absence of air-fluid levels, and no transition point, supports the diagnosis of paralytic ileus (vs small bowel obstruction).

Laboratory evaluation



The following laboratory tests can assess for potential causes or exacerbating factors for paralytic ileus:



  • Complete blood count:  to assess for anemia (eg, postoperative bleeding), inflammation, or infection (eg, abscess)
  • Electrolyte panel (to detect imbalances (eg, hypokalemia) that may exacerbate bowel dysmotility), renal function tests, liver function tests, and lipase
  • Blood glucose:  to detect long-standing diabetes mellitus that can cause gastroparesis, increasing the risk for postoperative ileus

Imaging studies



Abdominal x-ray is typically the first imaging modality used to evaluate for paralytic ileus, but a CT scan of the abdomen provides more detailed images to rule out mechanical obstruction (if unclear on x-ray) and to identify other inflammatory conditions that may contribute to paralytic ileus.



Characteristic imaging findings of paralytic ileus include (

image 6
):



  • Uniformly dilated loops of bowel in the small and large intestines (due to generalized bowel paralysis)
  • Air in the distal colon and rectum
  • No transition zone
  • No air-fluid levels


In contrast, patients with small bowel obstruction have proximal bowel dilation with a discrete point of transition to collapsed distal bowels.

Management



Postoperative ileus typically self-resolves as bowel motility gradually returns; therefore, treatment focuses on supportive care and addressing underlying causes.



  • Bowel rest:  Restrict oral intake to allow the bowel time to recover (then advance diet slowly as tolerated).
  • Antiemetics:  Administer to manage nausea and vomiting.
  • IV fluids:  Use to maintain adequate hydration while the patient is nauseated/vomiting and not taking hydration orally.
  • Nasogastric tube:  Use in cases of severe distension or intractable vomiting, to alleviate abdominal distension by draining the stomach contents and decompressing the small intestine.
  • Opioids and other medications:  Avoid these medications that slow gut motility (eg, anticholinergics).
  • Electrolyte correction:  Correct to address imbalances (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) that can worsen ileus.
  • Prokinetic agents:  Consider medications such as metoclopramide to stimulate bowel motility in certain cases, although their efficacy in paralytic ileus is limited.

Prognosis



The prognosis of paralytic ileus is generally favorable, especially if the underlying cause is identified and treated.  Postoperative ileus typically resolves within 3-5 days with conservative management.  However, complications such as bowel perforation, infection, or electrolyte derangements can arise in severe or prolonged cases.

Prevention



  • Laparoscopic (vs open) surgery reduces the risk of postoperative ileus.
  • Early ambulation after surgery can improve bowel motility.
  • Postoperative opioid use should be minimized.
  • Electrolyte monitoring and correction should be performed.

Summary



Paralytic ileus (

) involves intestinal hypomotility that can occur from a variety of conditions, the most common being abdominal surgery.  Reduction or cessation of peristalsis leads to bowel distension, which causes abdominal bloating, discomfort, and the inability to tolerate oral intake.  Characteristic clinical findings include hypoactive bowel sounds and diffuse dilation of both the small and large intestines, with gas in the colon and rectum and no transition point.  Treatment is mainly supportive (eg, fluids, bowel rest) because most cases resolve spontaneously with time.
